revision.comment: /* top */ As per MOS the list in the infobox must be plain
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Garay Latif oglu Asadov | native_name = Gəray Lətif oğlu Əsədov | image = Garay Asadov.jpg | birth_date = 1923 | death_date = {{deathdateandage|1944|10|12|1923|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Şahsevən, Beylagan|Shakhsevan]], [[TSFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_place = [[Marghita]], [[Romania]] | allegiance = Soviet Union | branch = [[Red Army]] | serviceyears = 1942{{endash}}1944 | rank = [[Sergeant]] | unit = [[93rd Guards Rifle Division]] | battles = {{plainlist| *[[World War II]] *[[Battle of Kursk]] *[[Battle of Debrecen]] }} | awards = {{plainlist| *{{Hero of the Soviet Union}} Hero of the Soviet Union *{{Order of Lenin}} Order of Lenin *[[Order of the Red Banner]] }} }}
'''Garay Latif oglu Asadov''' ({{Lang-az| Gəray Lətif oğlu Əsədov}}; 1923{{Endash}}12 October 1944) was an [[Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]] [[Red Army]] [[sergeant]] and a posthumous [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]. Asadov was posthumously awarded the title on 24 March 1945 for his actions during the [[Debrecen Offensive Operation]]. He was reported to have killed 16 German soldiers and was killed while covering a bunker opening with his body.<ref name=":1">Hero of the Soviet Union citation, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie150001526/ pamyat-naroda.ru]</ref><ref name=":0">{{Ruheroes|id=4451}}</ref>
== Early life == Asadov was born in 1923 in [[Şahsevən, Beylagan|Shakhsevan]]. He received primary education.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=http://www.az-libr.ru/index.htm?Persons&0H0/d2898717/index|title=Герои Советского Союза: Краткий биографический словарь|last=|first=|publisher=Voenizdat|year=1987|isbn=|editor-last=Shkadov|editor-first=Ivan|volume=1 Abaev-Lubitsch|location=Moscow|pages=82|language=Russian|trans-title=Heroes of the Soviet Union: A Brief Biographical Dictionary|via=}}</ref> Asadov worked on the kolkhoz after graduating.<ref name=":0" />
== World War II == Asadov was drafted into the Red Army in 1942 and fought in combat from June. He fought in the [[Battle of Kursk]], the capture of [[Right-bank Ukraine]], and [[Moldova]]. Asadov became a rifleman in the 281st Guards Rifle Regiment of the [[93rd Guards Rifle Division]]. In October 1944, he fought in the [[Battle of Debrecen]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":12" />
On 6 October, during the battle for [[Vlaha (Cluj)|Vlaha]], 10 kilometers southwest of [[Cluj-Napoca|Cluj]], Asadov reportedly killed more than 10 German soldiers with grenades. During the battle for [[Huedin]], he reportedly killed the crew of a German fire and opened fire on the German troops with it, reportedly killing more than 24 German soldiers. For his actions in Huedin, Asadov received the [[Order of the Red Banner]] on 30 November.<ref>Order No. 203 27th Army, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie44932072/ pamyat-naroda.ru]</ref> On 12 October, during the battle for [[Marghita]], a group of soldiers led by Asadov fought a 40-man German force. The Soviet troops attacked, reportedly killing 16 and capturing others. Later that day, in fighting for the railway station, Asadov reportedly covered the opening of a bunker with his body. On 24 March 1945, he was posthumously awarded the title Hero of the Soviet Union and the [[Order of Lenin]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":12" />
== Legacy == A sovkhoz and secondary school in Shakhsevan were named for Asadov, along with a street in [[Beylagan (city)|Beylagan]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":12" />
== References == <references />
